[MR SPEAKER IN THE CHAIR] MAIN AND DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES OF SINGAPORE FOR THE FINANCIAL YEAR 1ST APRIL, 1974 TO 31ST MARCH, 1975

Order read for resumed consideration in Committee of Supply [7th Allotted Day]. [MR SPEAKER IN THE CHAIR]

Head OA --

Mr Tay Boon Too (Paya Lebar)(In Mandarin): Sir, I beg to move,

That the sum to be allocated for Head OA be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead AA 1004*. (* The same amendment also stood in the names of Messrs N. Govindasamy, Cheong Yuen Chee, P. Govindaswamy and Lai Tha Chai.)

Sir, when the Government announced that all civil servants, including employees of statutory boards and aided school teachers, clerical staff and servants could opt for a reduced medical leave and in return compensated with a monetary allowance or Leave Allow-

ance, everyone was very happy. The civil servants were paid their allowance last year, whereas the teachers were paid only at the beginning of this year. It is immaterial as to whether the allowance was actually paid out earlier or later. But what is unreasonable and unfair is that the conversion to leave allowance for teachers and other teaching staff was back-dated to the 1st of November last year, whereas that for the other civil servants was back-dated to the 1st of January, 1973. We know that the salaries of civil servants in the various grades vary according to their qualifications and experience. Hence, there are salary scales for general Pass degree holders, professionals and non-professionals, skilled workers and non-skilled workers. There are different salary scales for different qualifications, and we have no quarrel about this. However, in the payment of an extra allowance which is given more or less for the same reason, then all of them should be

equally treated. There should not be any discrimination. For example, take the reduced medical leave allowance. All of us have traded our sick leave for a certain sum of money as allowance in return. It has nothing to do with academic qualifications or experience. Why is it that teachers had their medical leave allowance back-dated to only the 1st of October, 1973, whereas civil servants were more generously treated as they had their allowance back-dated to the 1st January, 1973? What is the rationale behind this? Teachers have complained as to why our Minister for Finance should treat them differently. They were treated like step-children by the Minister for Finance.

Sir, about two weeks ago when we had a debate on the Budget Statement, quite a number of Members spoke at length on the subject of personal relief from income tax. I do not want to dwell on this any more, but just to air my views concerning the reply given by the Minister on this subject. In his reply the Minister said that he had carefully considered the question of raising the amount of personal relief from income tax, but he said that if the request was acceded to, it would lead to increased expenditure in the other sectors. Therefore, he was of the opinion that it was not feasible at this stage to increase the amount of personal relief. The fact that the Minister had now re-assessed this subject shows that the amount of personal relief, which was fixed about 20 years ago, is already out of date and inappropriate in the light of present developments and inflationary trends. If the amount of personal relief is increased, it would result in the reduction of revenue.

But what I would like to ask the Minister is whether he has considered the possibility of getting those who are able and those who are well-off to bear the burden of taxation. We all know that the general run of wage earners is that they are living in difficulties. Their incomes are small and therefore it is not reasonable to tax them any further. The employers submit the annual returns on the incomes of their employees. Therefore, it is impossible for them to evade

any payment of taxes. On the other hand, the business houses in the private sector could look for loopholes in the Income Tax Act to evade payment of taxes. The Minister should plug these loopholes and see that there is no evasion of tax and should not ask the poor wage earners to pay unduly heavy taxes. It can be done unless the staff of the Income Tax Department do not want to enforce the relevant provisions of the law. The evasion of taxes by businessmen can be stopped.

The Chairman: Mr Tay, your 10 minutes are up.

Mr N. Govindasamy (Telok Blangah): Sir, under this amendment, I just want to congratulate the Minister and commend him for introducing the Singapore Allowance for pensioners. However, when he replied to a Question for oral answer on 15th March, it was pointed out to him that among the pensioners, those who retired before 1969 had their pensions computed on the basic wage drawn by them prior to the time of retirement, and that those who retired after 1969 had their pensions calculated on a consolidated wage which included the cost of living allowance. It is, therefore, unfair to older pensioners drawing lesser pensions through no fault of their own. When this point was raised a few days ago, the Minister did not reply, but said that it was a separate question altogether. The Minister himself being an ex-civil servant would appreciate the need for Government to look after its old and faithful servants. I implore the Minister to reconsider the case of the few pensioners who retired before 1969 and to pay them pensions computed on their consolidated wage instead of their basic wage.

Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Sir, it has been a long time since chit fund companies were wound up. Up to now the public has not been told anything about the results of the winding-up, except for the punishment meted out on the directors. Anxious citizens are waiting to see how much can they recover from their losses. How long have these ex-subscribers got to wait to recover

their losses? At the rate we are going, by the time the payment is made, the amount will be diminished to peanuts. Would the Minister tell us what action is being taken in this respect?

2.45 p.m.

I would like to know the present ruling governing the account of a C.P.F, member who dies and who had, on his nomination form, named a person who had since died. Is it true that the nomination form of the C.P.F, is similar to a will, and therefore in such a case the family of the deceased nominee could put a claim through the public trustee? Could the Minister enlighten me on this matter?

The economic survey of Singapore has been very well planned and written. Figures quoted in the annual Budget Statement are apt and they really show the precise situation. I note that the "oil crisis" and the consequent economic slow-down in the industrial countries, world-wide inflation, international trade and the international monetary system have affected our otherwise booming economy. It is indeed sad to note this fact. However, much credit goes to the planning of the Government to off-set these ills and to rectify deficiencies wherever they exist because of these factors.

The oil crisis, or what could be termed as our own oil financial crisis, is going to be a permanent feature of Singapore's life. Anyone who believes that the oil-producing countries are going to lower their oil prices to the pre-October level is living in a fool's paradise. As such, it is time we introduced legislation not only to conserve our oil supplies, but also to make sure that our foreign exchange is not drained out by buying oil at prohibitive prices. May I ask what measures have been taken to make sure that shopping complexes, business houses and hotels reduce their lighting to the barest minimum? Up to-date what other measures has the Finance Ministry taken to deal with this energy crisis?

Raising the question of reducing wastage is an important one. Government should revamp and revive all the special campaigns that it used to have some time back. The TV and radio should increase the number of warnings on the conservation of energy and "save more" campaigns.

In the Budget proper, we welcome the statement requiring all Ministries and Departments to cut down wastage and unnecessary expenditures. These are two very important aspects of our economic life. The Minister also stated that there is no let-up in the implementation of desirable development programmes and projects. I would like to know how these proposals are going to be checked.

Though there is now publicity in the press and on the air about inflation, something concrete must be done if our lower and middle income group citizens are to survive. Prices of essential commodities have risen by about 200-300 per cent. Prices are still rising. Every day a new price is quoted by the shopkeepers and hawkers. When asked, some of them say that the Government has allowed them to raise the prices of goods. Shopkeepers and hawkers seem to round up their prices to the nearest 5 or 10 cents in any price increase. This is because of the lack of I-cent coins. Is there any method that can be adopted to prevent the customers from being cheated because of the hack of 1-cent coins? More effective price controls must be substituted. Has the Price Control Department appointed sufficient inspectors to check on prices? Shopkeepers and hawkers are adopting the "take it or leave it" attitude which hits the poor below the belt. The people welcome statements followed by action, such as the black-listing of bakeries producing short-weight bread.

In conjunction with this there should be more NTUC Welcome Supermarkets. These are fast becoming popular. The people are heeding the call by the Trade Division to boycott shops selling goods at exorbitant prices. But there have been cases where the price of an article in the Welcome Supermarket was higher by as much as $2 for the same article sold by the shopkeepers outside. A case in point

is the Thomson Road Market where a tin of cooking oil was sold for $6 whereas it costs $7.15 at the Toa Payoh Welcome Supermarket. Why should there be such a vast difference in price? This will discourage the consumer from buying at Toa Payoh. Can an attempt be made to check the prices in Welcome Supermarkets against prices in the other shops, so as to make the Supermarket prices attractive to customers? This is the time to do it, as supermarkets are becoming popular. In this way we can easily check profiteering by the retailers. I would request the Price Control Department, CASE and INTRACO to play their very important role in the control of prices of goods in the Welcome Supermarkets, and try to make them more attractive.

Moreover, some of the fresh foods like meat, fish and vegetables in the markets are as old as Noah's Ark. Cannot something be done to have them changed or auctioned to the public, and new stocks brought in? It is better to sell at a cheaper price than to allow them to perish.

Sir, I am glad to note that the Government has taken the necessary measures, without harming any sector of the economy, to diversify the sources of our most essential food supplies, and to revive a scheme for a rice stockpile. Welcome and SAFE Supermarkets should be activated to fight against inflation.

As a result of the tourist boom a decade ago, the Government encouraged people to build hotels. What has been done to alleviate the plight of hotel owners by bringing in more tourists and so increase the occupancy of hotel rooms? Have our foreign missions played any significant part in this respect? It has been quite some time now since Government began its industrialisation programme.

Up to-date very little propaganda activity has been organised for the sale of Singapore made goods. What action is the Government taking in this regard? We have, in the past, been emphasising on the promotion of our Singapore made goods. It is time that we placed greater

emphasis on the promotion of our locally made products, both locally and abroad, so as to compete with foreign goods.

Sir, a daily peep of the newspaper reveals that our youths are involved in some form of activity or other. Youth problems of the Republic today are different from those of the past. In view of the far-sighted policies of our Government, there is an urgent need for an effective youth council to be formed in the Republic, where greater participation of our youth in more responsible activity can be looked into.

Sir, it has been suggested in the past that deserving officers be given merit increments as an incentive to work hard. How many officers have so far benefited from this scheme?

There is hardly any difference in the output of work between clerical assistants and clerical officers. Yet the clerical assistants are paid less than clerical officers. It can be a terribly frustrating experience for clerical assistants, with the same qualifications as clerical officers, to work in the same office with clerical officers and doing the same job but paid less instead.

The Chairman: Your time is up, Mr P. Govindaswamy. Mr Lai?

Mr Lai Tha Chai (Henderson): I am not speaking, Sir.

Mr Yeo Choo Kok (Delta): Sir, we hear so much about the credit squeeze these days. Indeed, in his Budget Statement a few days ago, the Minister has outlined the fiscal measures adopted to counter inflation. However, the average man-in-the-street or the petty trader is still confused as to what is going on. When he approaches his bank or finance company for credit facilities, he is either turned away or asked to pay fantastic rates of interest which all goes to add to his cost which, in turn, he will obviously pass on to his customers. This will inevitably help to accelerate the rate of inflation.

Sir, I would like to request the Minister to inform the House of the specific areas where such a squeeze is

being applied, and whether the measures taken hitherto have the desired effect. In one of his recent statements in this House, the Minister mentioned that the economic prospects of the world now looked rather more optimistic. I would like to know when the Minister is going to relax the squeeze, in the light of this remark. There are also fears expressed that if the squeeze goes on for too long the foreign investor will be frightened away, and this will slow down the economy of the country to such an extent that it might be impossible to pick up later on. Sir, I hope that the credit squeeze will not squeeze the economic life out of this country in the long run.

Mr Ho Kah Leong (Jurong): Sir, yesterday in this Chamber when we were talking about agriculture, I said that it was my duty as a rural MP to raise the point that the lifting of import tax on frozen chicken had caused considerable hardship to our poultry farmers. In fact, as far as I know, some of them have already given up poultry rearing as a result of this measure. The Minister for Law and National Development in his reply informed the House that this was a matter for the Ministry of Finance, and that his Ministry was strongly in favour of reimposing the import tax on frozen chicken.

Sir, I would like to take this opportunity to ask the Minister for Finance what is the reaction of his Ministry on this matter, and when will the import tax on frozen chicken be reimposed.

Mr Ivan Baptist (Potong Pasir): Sir, the Singaporean is worried about inflation. Government is worried about inflation. CASE is worried about inflation. The trade unions are worried about inflation. And so am I! I am just wondering how far will this go, and will Government assist us Singaporeans to cushion the effects of inflation? I am wondering whether the Minister can tell us whether he will, in the few months to come, increase taxes on petrol, motor vehicles and other items, or whether he will assist us by lifting tariffs on more consumer commodities.

The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Sir, there are quite a number of questions to be answered, particularly from the Member for Anson, but I will answer them in the order in which they were posed.

The Member for Paya Lebar asked why the scheme of allowance in lieu of medical leave for employees in the civil service and statutory boards was implemented on 1st January, 1973, whereas for teachers this was made effective only from October, 1973. He wanted to know the rationale for this. First of all, I want to make it quite clear that there has never been an allowance in lieu of medical leave, as such. The proposal which Government made to the unions was for the payment of leave allowance in lieu of reduced leave. That means reduced vacation leave.

3.00 p.m.

The purpose and objective of this proposal was to solve the growing problem of accumulation of vacation leave by employees in the civil service, most of whom have very little likelihood of ever being able to use up their accumulated leave. There was no such problem with teachers who enjoyed a different leave scheme and still enjoy it, and who have their own school holidays. Teachers were, therefore, excluded from the proposal from the beginning. There was, as I said, no intention to provide monetary compensation for reduction of medical leave alone for any employees in the public service. However, in the negotiations with the unions, compensation for reduction of medical leave was included as part of a package settlement.

Because of this settlement, representations were also made by the Education Ministry, by the Teachers' Union, and also by the Member for Moulmein (whose services have not apparently been entirely appreciated) for the concession of monetary compensation for reduction of medical leave alone to be extended to teachers who are also enjoying school holidays. I must stress that this suggestion was not initiated nor desired by the Treasury, and there was

indeed very considerable reluctance of my Ministry to accept it. But finally we accepted it with reluctance.

This was a matter subsequent to and separate from the proposal for leave allowance in lieu of reduced vacation leave, and therefore it was thought appropriate that a different effective date for implementation should be used. As the scheme for reduced medical leave for teachers was accepted by the Teachers' Union sometime in September 1973, the effective date was to be 1st October, 1973, in accordance with the normal Treasury practice of adopting the first of the month following agreement as the date of implementation. In the case of the main scheme for the public service, 1st January, 1973, was adopted as the effective date because general agreement on the scheme was reached in September, 1972, following consultations between officials of my Ministry and those of several trade unions representing employees in the public service.

The Member for Paya Lebar also referred to my explanation, during the debate on the financial policy of the Government, that in considering the question of giving personal relief I had decided that, other than the tax relief increase for dependent parents and grandparents, there should be no concession in the way of personal relief. He thought this decision was inappropriate in the light of present developments and that, as the rate had been the same for the last 20 years, it was out of date. In this respect, of course, I have to consider not only whether the rate which has obtained over the last 20 years gives the same or more revenue, but also whether, in fact, there is now very much more expenditure which will have to be covered by fresh revenue. So it does mean that if reliefs were given resulting in less revenue, then I would have to consider applying a tax in some other way which would make good the loss in revenue and which would be sufficient to cover the very much greater additional expenditure, since the rate of personal relief was decided 20 years ago.

Now, I think a word on the income tax system may not be inappropriate

here. This system is progressive in its effect, the higher income earner paying a higher rate of tax. So from the point of view of imposing taxation, if any method has to be used, this would be as appropriate, if not more appropriate, a method as any other. The existing reliefs already ensure that only taxpayers who are in the middle and higher income brackets are liable to pay the tax. As an example, in 1972 only 126,000 persons, or 17 per cent out of a total of 725,000 who were gainfully employed, paid any income tax. A taxpayer supporting, say, a wife, two children and two parents, would therefore be liable to pay tax only if his annual income exceeds $7,000. Generally, therefore, the lower income groups do not pay income tax, and any upward revision of personal relief would benefit only those who can afford to make some contribution to Government revenue.

The international view of Singapore income taxation is that we are rather generous in our personal reliefs and we would do well to broaden the base of such taxation. In fact, if our taxation were examined further, it may be that next year we shall have to reduce the rate of personal relief rather than increase it. Psychologically, it would bring home to the new taxpayers that Government grants, subsidies and concessions, which are being so liberally advocated by Members, can come only out of the generosity of taxpayers among whom perhaps many of the advocates can be numbered.

The Member for Telok Blangah asked a question regarding the extension of pension benefits to officers who retired before the consolidation of salaries. He would like the present method of computing pension based on the consolidated salary to be also given to those officers who retired before the setting up of the Salaries Commission. I have had representations from pensioners as well as the Member for Telok Blangah and I have considered them, and I will always consider representations which are made from time to time. But this is really a very hardy and perennial question, and I cannot really hold out any hope that Government will extend

the present method of computing pension based on consolidated salary to those officers who retired before 1-1-69 when pension was computed on the basis of basic salary without taking into account the variable allowances. The exercise to consolidate salaries in 1969 was intended to improve the terms and conditions of service of officers who were then in service, and of others who would be joining the service subsequently. It was not intended to increase the pension of those pensioners who had already retired from the service before 1969. Officers who retired before 1969 on non-consolidated salaries are already being assisted in that they are paid a cost of living allowance and a Singapore allowance if their pensions are (a) below $257 per month, and they have no dependants, or (b) below $331 per month, and have dependants to support. On the other hand, officers who retired on consolidated salaries are not paid this cost of living allowance and Singapore allowance, so that if the pension for officers who retired before 1969 on non-consolidated salaries were to be recomputed as though they had their salaries consolidated, and if they were to give up accordingly the cost of living allowance and Singapore allowance, then about 73 per cent of such pensioners would be receiving less pension. I do not know whether the Member for Telok Blangah intended to have this particular effect.

Mr N. Govindasamy: Oh, no!

Mr Hon Sui Sen: I come now to the questions of the Member for Anson. He has touched on a very considerable number of topics, some of which are not really under my jurisdiction or may only be partially so. Nevertheless, I shall try to answer him where I can. First of all, I think he said that the public has not been kept informed of the results of the winding-up of certain chit fund companies. I think this is incorrect because a press release was made on 19th December, 1973, announcing the initial dividend payment for seven chit fund companies being wound up by the Official Receiver. To-date, five companies

have paid dividends. Another two companies will make payments of dividends before the end of May, 1974. The Government is aware that the verification of claims for the various chit fund companies that are wound up since late 1972 has taken considerable time. This is inevitable as the process of verification depends on the co-operation of the creditors and the substantiation of their claims at the Official Receiver's Office. Until each member's account has been verified, it is not possible for the Official Receiver to declare a dividend.

3.15 p.m.

The Member also sought some clarification on CPF matters which no doubt my colleague, the Minister for Labour, would be better able to answer. But I believe that when a member of the Fund dies and if the person nominated by him to receive his credit balance had died before the member, the amount will be paid to the public trustee to be disposed of in accordance with the law for the time being in force. If the nominee of the deceased member dies after the demise of the member, the amount due to the nominee will be paid to the estate of the deceased nominee. I hope that clarifies the point raised by him.

The Member for Anson then touched on the Government's "Save Energy" campaign. He must already be aware of the effects of the campaign which began last November and the result of the efforts of the public to restrict consumption of petroleum fuel and electricity. We made a list of suggestions to guide the public in the efficient use of fuel and electricity and gave extensive coverage in the local newspapers, radio and television to this campaign. During the last few months, the PUB sent out inspectors all round the island to ensure that there was no unnecessary lighting and that advertising lights were switched off after 9 p.m. Since the commencement of the "Save Energy" campaign, the weekly consumption of electricity, as most Members would know, has declined by an average of 10 per cent.

The Control of Essential Supplies Act and the Restrictions on the Supply, Distribution and Use of Petroleum and Electricity Act enacted last year give the Government legal powers to take action against any wasteful consumption of energy, as and when necessary. I think the recent increase in the tariff rates for electricity would also act as a deterrent against excessive consumption of fuel and electricity. I think the Member also touched on alternative measures to develop new sources of energy. The PUB is replanning Stage II development of Senoko Power Station to incorporate a dual firing system which allows the use of either gas or fuel oil. The possibility of burning coal is also being examined. Another possibility, as far back as 1971, is that the Government has considered the introduction of a nuclear-based power station in the Republic. Studies involving the siting of a nuclear power station are in progress. Detailed investigations on the environmental effects of such a plant and the necessity for additional safeguards against dangers to nearby areas of high density population in Singapore are being carried out with the assistance of the International Atomic Energy Agency.

The Member for Anson also asked how we check on development proposals. This is a rather complicated procedure. Presumably he has in mind the check aimed at ensuring that only desirable projects are allowed to go ahead. Generally, if any project falls within the framework of Government's major policies, it is prima facie a desirable project. My officials examine the various aspects of the projects, such as their scale, location, phasing, alternative aspects to achieve the same objectives and so on. When the projects have been properly evaluated, they are submitted to a Ministerial Committee, called the Development Planning Committee, for approval. Subsequently, the technical details are further vetted by the Development Planning Sub-Committee to ensure that there is no extravagance in the choice of materials or designs.

The Member has also touched on inflation and price controls. I have already explained in my Budget Statement

in some detail the action we have taken, and I have explained the undesirability of price control in general as an anti-inflationary measure. I have also explained the measures that Government has taken to dampen the price escalation, including action against profiteers and the promotion of consumer co-operatives - rather than fixing prices, it is more appropriate to disseminate information on prices and stocks to consumers to enable them to differentiate between unscrupulous add dependable traders, thereby enabling them to protect their own interest. Only when consumers, armed with this information, refrain from buying from high-priced shops and make selective purchases from shops which sell at fair prices can the Government's efforts be assured of success. In the long run this is the only way to deal with sellers who round up their prices to the next five or ten cents, as complained by the Member. At the end of 1973, there were 35 million one-cent coins recorded as being in circulation, and there is really no excuse for sellers not to fix prices to the cent, especially for the lower priced goods where a few cents represent a significant percentage of the price. If there is any difficulty in getting one-cent coins, I think the Currency Board is always ready to issue more coins.

The existing machinery in the Department of Trade for the dissemination of price and supply information and the investigation of complaints on profiteering will be consolidated. The Singapore Manufacturers Association will also be helping in the fight against profiteering by, firstly, doing their best to print the prices upon their products wherever possible and, secondly, keeping the Department of Trade informed of price increases.

The Member for Anson mentioned that he was aware of over-charging by CASE or the Welcome Supermarket. Perhaps he should forward his inquiries to the Member for Potong Pasir and the Member for Boon Teck. However, if I am asked to answer this particular question, I would venture to say that for a limited range of goods the prices charged in the small retail shops can

occasionally be lower than the prices charged in the NTUC Welcome Supermarket. In the case of cooking oil mentioned by the Member for Anson, as prices increase some retailers who have stocks purchased at the old prices may be able to sell at the old retail prices, while popular organisations like the NTUC Welcome Supermarkets, where the turnover is much more rapid, have to pay higher prices for new stocks and are, therefore, compelled to charge higher retail prices. In any case, these prices provide a reference to what charges would be fair. The discriminating shopper should, therefore, take advantage of any lower prices and buy if he can from shops which sell more cheaply. I do not expect the NTUC Supermarket to object to this.

The Member for Anson also spoke on tourist promotion. He may recall that in 1973 Singapore passed the millionth visitor's mark, and there was an increase of 28.9 per cent in the tourist traffic over the previous year. The hotel occupancy rate in 1972 was 61 per cent and this rose to 67.2 per cent in 1973, despite the increase in the number of hotel rooms from 8,358 in 1972 to 9,413 in 1973. This achievement was largely due to the tourist promotion and publicity efforts overseas by the Tourist Promotion Board and other bodies such as the Singapore Airlines. A major portion of the Tourist Promotion Board budget has been expended for this purpose. Our foreign missions have always supplemented the efforts of the Singapore Tourist Promotion Board in promoting Singapore as a tourist centre by the dissemination of tourist brochures and information. However, since tourist promotion is a specialised function, this is done more extensively by the overseas offices of the Singapore Tourist Promotion Board which are established in countries such as the United States, Germany, Japan and Australia, the major tourist markets.

The Member also suggested action for promoting sales of locally made goods. The Government has always been conscious of the need for export promotion

and the Exports Promotion Unit was initially set up in the Economic Development Division to fulfil this function in line with an active trade policy to widen domestic and overseas markets for manufactured goods. Since 1972 this Unit has been transferred to the Department of Trade. The Unit maintains a library service to provide both product and area information. A number of seminars have been organised to help medium and small-sized manufacturers to break into the export market. The Unit through the Commercial Secretary stationed in Singapore missions overseas also help traders and manufacturers to get in touch with foreign buyers. At the same time, buyers are actively encouraged to come to Singapore. 7.51 p.m.

The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

In accordance with Article 85 of the Constitution of Singapore, heads of expenditure to be met from the Consolidated Fund, other than Statutory Expenditure, have to be included in the Bill to be known as the Supply Bill.

The purpose of the Supply Bill before Members is, therefore, to give legislative approval for the appropriations from the Consolidated Fund to meet expenditure in the financial year 1st April, 1974, to 31st March, 1975.

In the Schedule to the Bill, the various heads of expenditure and the sums that may be incurred in respect of each head are shown. These have been approved by the House in the Main Estimates of Expenditure for the financial year 1st

April, 1974, to 31st March, 1975, and appear on pages 45, 46 and 47 of Cmd. Paper No. 5 of 1974.

The Supply Bill, when approved, will empower me to issue warrants authorising expenditure up to the amount for each head as shown in the Bill to be paid out from the Consolidated Fund.

Sir, I beg to move.

Question put, and agreed to.
